Richard Hofstadter was an American historian and political scientist. He was born in 1916 and died in 1970. He is widely regarded as one of the most prominent and influential historians of the 20th century, known for his work on the history of American politics and culture. Hofstadter graduated from Columbia University, where he earned his PhD in 1942. He taught at various universities throughout his career, including Columbia, where he was a professor of history for many years. Hofstadter's most famous book, "The American Political Tradition," was published in 1948, and it is still widely read and studied today. The book is a critique of American political leaders from the founding of the country to the mid-20th century. Hofstadter also wrote several other influential books, including "The Age of Reform," which won the Pulitzer Prize in History in 1956, and "Anti-Intellectualism in American Life," which won the Pulitzer Prize in General Nonfiction in 1964.

Hofstadter also wrote an article, "The Paranoid Style in American Politics," which was published in Harper's Magazine in November 1964, in which he used the term "conspiracy theory" to describe a certain type of political attitude. Hofstadter argued that "the paranoid spokesman sees the fate of conspiracy in apocalyptic terms—he traffics in the birth and death of whole worlds, whole political orders, whole systems of human values" and that "he is always manning the barricades of civilization". Hofstadter's work continues to be widely read and studied in the field of American history and political science.
